Award.AwardTitle: ELUCID - Exploring the Local Universe with Reconstructed Initial Density Field
Award.AbstractNarration:
The nearby universe shows clumpy structures, such as stars and planetary systems, galaxies, and clusters of galaxies, arranged in a beautiful yet complex cosmic web. The distant, early universe appears much smoother. The question of how clumpy structures formed from a smooth early universe remains an exciting astrophysical mystery. Furthermore, the interaction of galaxies and their surrounding intergalactic medium is also a matter of intense current research. This project addresses important questions about the formation of structure in the universe over 14 billions years of cosmic history. The researchers will seek to answer questions that include: What drives the formation of the large-scale structure we observe and how do galaxies like the Milky Way form and evolve in the cosmic web?  Are simple physical laws as we understand today able to reproduce the complex structures in the vast cosmos, as well as their interaction with each other? The project will also support the work and professional training of a graduate student in astrophysics, parallel computing, and computer visualization. Movies about the time evolution of matter (both dark and visible) in the universe will be made to allow the public to witness how simple physical principles can be used to reproduce the complex structures in the vast cosmos.

The researchers will develop a new method, using numerical simulations and semi-analytical modeling, to reconstruct initial conditions from which the cosmic density field in the low-redshift universe has evolved; simulate the cosmic density field in both dark matter and gas using the reconstructed initial conditions; and study the relationship between galaxies, dark halos, dark matter, and the intergalactic medium to test theories of galaxy formation. The accuracy of this new method and its reliability will be quantified using detailed numerical simulations. Simulations will be run multiple times to explore cosmic variance. An output from this work will be a mock SDSS catalog, available to explore the comparison between observations and theory directly. The results of this research will provide insight into the processes that shape galaxies and large-scale structures, as well as the relationship between galaxies, and their environments and dark matter.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A key step in understanding galaxy formation in the Universe is to study the distributions and properties of galaxies and the intergalactic medium (IGM), and their interactions with each other and with dark matter. Detailed observations of the low-z galaxy population are now available from large surveys (e.g. the SDSS). The hot diffuse gas can be studied through its SZ effect (e.g. SPT, ACT and PLANCK) and the warm/hot medium through QSO absorption line observations (e.g. HST/COS). These together provide an unprecedented data set to study how galaxies form and evolve in the cosmic web and how the IGM is affected by feedback from galaxies. To take full advantage of the data requires an optimized strategy. Simulations are limited by their dynamic range, and to resolve processes on galaxy scales usually requires the simulation volumes to be much smaller than the large-scale structure. Observationally, finite sample volumes can lead to biased views of the large-scale structure and the galaxy population. The uncertainties can be minimized if comparisons are made for systems having the same environments and formation histories. The main objective of the proposed research is to develop an accurate and efficient method to reconstruct the initial conditions for the formation of the structures in which the observed galaxy population resides and from which the actual gas emission and absorption are produced, so that one can compare observations and model simulations objectively, and make full use of the observational data. The method uses galaxy groups/clusters selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) as proxies of dark matter halos to reconstruct both the underlying density field in the local Universe and the initial conditions responsible for its formation and evolution.
To achieve the main goal of the proposed approach, we have  developed a new method of reconstruction and quantified its accuracy and reliability using detailed numerical simulations. We have also reconstructed the initial conditions from which the cosmic density field in the local universe has evolved, and simulated the local cosmic density field in both dark matter and gas using our reconstructed initial density field. The constrained simulations and the products of our reconstruction have been used to study the relationships between galaxies, dark halos, dark matter, and the IGM in different environments of the local Universe, and  to investigate halo and galaxy assembly histories and IGM properties in varying environments. These activities and their results provided unprecedented insight into the processes that shape galaxies, the IGM, and large-scale structure in the observed Universe. Observations have revealed the existence of millions of galaxies like the Milky Way in the low-z Universe and that their distribution in space forms a beautiful and yet complex cosmic web. What drives the formation of the large-scale structure we observe and how galaxies like the Milky Way form and evolve in the cosmic web are questions fascinating not only to cosmologists but also to the general public. The reconstruction of the origin and subsequent evolution of the structure in the low-z Universe provide a unique avenue to understand how these fundamental questions can be addressed and answered in science. Movies of the time evolution of dark-matter and luminous matter distributions are made to allow the general public to witness how simple physical principles can be used to reproduce the complex structures in the vast cosmos, promoting public interest in programs supported by NSF and other funding agencies.
